bibl.title: Despatch from William H. Heard to Edwin F. Uhl
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.note: Index Bureau Dept of State Rec'd Aug 23 1895
div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States
Monrovia Liberia July 10/95

William H. Heard
To the Department of State
Loss by Exchange by Vice Consul

Consulate General of the U.S.
Monrovia Liberia July 10, 1895

Hon. Edwin F. Uhl
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington D.C.

I have the honor to enclose the explanation of Vice Consul Beverly Y. Payne for the Auditor of the Treasury. I find that to change drafts here one must loose 2 0/0, 3 0/0 and 4 0/0, never less than 2 0/0, and that an English Sterling is $4.80 only. Do we loose in all our transactions 86.65 on every sterling. But there
are a few persons who can furnish United States Currency, and it is dollar for a dollar. Every Gold dollar. Every Silver dollar and every paper note is worth 100 cents.

I am obediently
William H. Heard
Min Res. and Con. General

Enclosure 1
Explanation of Vice Consul Payne
